instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message:
Hello,

I have an issue with an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B board. Board was liquid damaged - put it through the ultrasonic cleaner and powered it up - green light and fan spinning. Great! Disconnected magsafe and went to have something to eat. Came back 10 minutes later will not power on: gets green light but will not power on at all. I have the following readings:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.62V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.497
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.337
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 5.01V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>: 0V


Got a weird issue where I get a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> when the machine is plugged in but the short goes away after you leave the magsafe unplugged for a while?

Any help would be appreciated with where to check next. Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: Where was wather damage?? Check RTC resistors (<RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R1803</RESISTOR>) should have around 3.3V on both sides.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message:
Water Damage on top of board around EFI chip, SMC and thunderbolt chip and similar area on the other side of the board.

RTC resistor values:

<RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>: 3.332V pin 1 3.236V pin 2
<RESISTOR>R1801</RESISTOR>: 3.332V pin 1 3.057 pin 2
<RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR>: 3.332V pin 1 3.327 pin 2
<RESISTOR>R1803</RESISTOR>: 3.332V pin 1 3.327 pin 2

<RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>: 325K
<RESISTOR>R1801</RESISTOR>: 1M
<RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR>: 20K
<RESISTOR>R1803</RESISTOR>: 20K


Checked some other voltages:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0V

Signal for these comes ultimately from <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> so guessing a dead MCP?

Reverse diode reading on <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>: 0.006 so guessing I have a short there also?

Time to give up on this rabbit hole to hell?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: No MCP on this board, i guess you mean PCH....... Check for any missing or corroded component around SMC and bios chip, replace all bad parts, also you can try apply flux and heat SMC to remove the crap under the chip.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message:
Sorry PCH! I'm new this this when it comes to the advanced hit your head against a wall stuff. Tried reflowing the SMC with flux to get rid of any crap under the chip but didn't change anything nothing really corroded around the area. As far as I can diagnose it will not go into an S3 state because it's not getting the correct enable signals which seem to come from <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>.

Guessing this is most likely an SMC or PCH issue? Yay!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL> comes high for a second or nothing at all??? If you have a slow multimiter, may not be readed, so use osciloscope if you have....

Could be bios problem, double check SPI lines and resistors, do continuity test............

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: Nothing at all on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>. Replaced BIOS - no change. Have given up on this one for now thanks for the help anyway.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: Replaced RTC Chip <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> and I get an S0 state and the fan is spinning! No video output or chime though - will keep investigating but at least that's one problem solved! Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: Put back original bios.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: Have done I think I have a <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> problem as a few burnt probe points around those. Will check further and get back to you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message:
OK new issue: machine turns on but I get no video output. I have no voltage on <SIGNAL>PVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>. All other main voltage rails appear to be present.

I get a reverse diode reading on both of these CPU rails of 0.002V with <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> removed.

Is this a normal diode reading or does it seem like I have a short to ground on the CPU side?

If so how do I go around figuring out what's causing it - if I inject voltage here from a bench power supply the CPU gets hot but this would make sense as the CPU is turning on. It's hard to work out if anything else is getting hot and shorting though?

Apologies if I'm missing/doing something stupid I've never had any <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> or CPU Voltage problems before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message:
Quick update. I replaced <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> and I now get 1.118V on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> but get 0V on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>.

Any ideas of what to check next? I read in another forum that BIOS can cause this so I replaced the BIOS chip again but still no luck. Thanks so much!! Hopefully I'm near the end of fixing this absolute nightmare board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: Display is plugged in??? this voltage comes up when display is detected...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: Yes - plugged everything back in and I get a solid sleep light on the front, DVD drive does it's auto eject thing like it's about to POST and then nothing. No video ouput on display and 0.001V on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: When the DVD drive does it's auto eject thing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> goes down from 1.118V to 0.919V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: I get a beep when no RAM installed. I'll go back to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and check all the resistors. I swear this board is a rite of passage from the repair gods to test my patience

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message:
Had a look around <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and cant find anything else that looks bad. 

I removed <RESISTOR>R7550</RESISTOR> and get voltage to pin 1 (think it was around 1V) as soon as I replace <RESISTOR>R7550</RESISTOR> I get 0V on Pins 3, 4, and 5 on <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> and 0V on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>.

Dead CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: picture on external monitor if you use thunderbolt to vga adapter?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 2569"]picture on external monitor if you use thunderbolt to vga adapter?[/QUOTE]

Nothing. I put back the BIOS chip from my donor board to see what happens and I got no drop in voltage on cpu vcore or signs of trying to POST. it could be a BIOS issue after all as original spill was around that area. Will order in another and pray

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: If it beeps all power is ok and POST runs. It can still hang during POST for 1000 reasons. Probably corroded resistor or crap under PCH/SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green Light No Power
threads.message: Cheers have given up on this rabbit hole to hell especially as I don't have decent enough tools at the moment to do any large scale BGA rework but was a good learning experience nonetheless getting the clock signal and CPU voltage back. Thanks again for all your help.
